title: The IndyStar brings justice to Nassar victims
text:
USA Gymnastics coverage team, from left, editor Steve Berta, reporters Mark Alesia, Marisa Kwiatkowski, Tim Evans, and visual journalist Robert Scheer in front of redacted documents from a sexual misconduct file that USA Gymnastics kept on a member coach, Star newsroom, Indianapolis, Thursday, April 6, 2017. The investigation uncovered hidden sexual abuse complaints sent to USAG about member coaches, and led to the arrest and conviction of Dr. Larry Nassar, the organization's former team doctor. (Photo: Kelly Wilkinson/IndyStar)

USA TODAY NETWORK is especially proud of The Indianapolis Star’s investigative reporters whose commitment to impactful journalism was highlighted by the sentencing of former USA Gymnastics doctor Larry Nassar this week. In August 2016, the IndyStarbroke the story about USA Gymnastics’ failure to report allegations of sexual abuse by coaches to authorities. Following publication of that stunning “Out of Balance” piece, Rachael Denhollander of Louisville, Ky., courageously emailed the IndyStar explaining that Dr. Larry Nassar had abused her under the guise of medical treatment, and in September 2016, the IndyStar broke the news about Nassar, who was working at Michigan State University at the time.

“We are proud of IndyStar’s dogged reporting and in awe of the victims’ courage to share their stories, which led to Nassar’s sentencing,” said Maribel Perez Wadsworth, president, USA TODAY NETWORK. “The conversation they have started about sexual abuse will continue to make an impact in the sports world and beyond. This week underscored why we do what we do as journalists.”

“It’s not often that a story has such broad and sustained impact. Our newsroom truly rallied around the coverage. The time and expense of this investigation was not small, but we felt that it paled in comparison to the importance of the story,” said Jeff Taylor, Midwest regional editor for the USA TODAY NETWORK and VP of News/Indianapolis. “We are grateful for the support of the broader USA TODAY NETWORK, which helped amplify the story to a national audience, and to the newsroom in Lansing, which played a crucial role as the Nassar story unfolded.”

Led by editors Jeff Taylor, Ronnie Ramos, Alvie Lindsay and Steve Berta (who supervises investigations), IndyStar journalists Marisa Kwiatkowski, Tim Evans, Mark Alesia and Robert Scheer have continued to diligently follow the story about USA Gymnastics for nearly two years. In 2017, they were recognized for their efforts with the prestigious Tom Renner Award, a national honor from Investigative Reporters and Editors. Other awards include:

Finalist in print/online (medium circulation) category for “Out of Balance,” Investigative Reporters and Editors contest

Top ten in investigative reporting for “Out of Balance,” Associated Press Sports Editors contest

Story of the year in the Society of Professional Journalists’ Best of Indiana Journalism contest

Legacy House, a nonprofit in Indiana, presented an award to the IndyStar “in recognition for support to victims of violence.”

Most importantly, “Out of Balance” helped lead to Nassar’s sentencing of 40 to 175 years in prison. One hundred and fifty six other women have bravely shared their experiences while standing in front of him in court over the past week and a half. They are the very reason for the IndyStar reporters’ passionate efforts. The Lansing Journal and The Detroit Free Press, both members of the USA TODAY NETWORK, have also contributed crucial coverage of Nassar’s case and trial.

At Nassar’s sentencing Wednesday, Michigan Assistant Attorney General Angela Povilaitis emphasized the important role journalists play in illuminating stories hidden in the darkness of society. "We as a society need investigative journalists more than ever," Povilaitis said. "What finally started this reckoning and ended this decades-long cycle of abuse was investigative reporting."

The reporting has received national recognition from the likes of the New York Times,Washington Post,Fast Company,CNN and USA TODAY.

Beyond that, journalists have taken to social media to express their appreciation for the investigative reporting about USA Gymnastics.

CNN’s Jake Tapper tweeted, “Also deserving of huge praise in bringing about this day of reckoning: The Indianapolis Star. @indystar Thank you for the work you do.”

Adam Goldman of The New York Times tweeted, “When the @indystar published in 2016 its stories on USA Gymnastics’ failure to protect young athletes, I thought the paper deserved a @PulitzerPrize. I still think that today. You rarely see this kind of impact in journalism.”

Kelly McBride of Poynter said on Twitter, “Important to note: this investigation was done by local journalists at the IndyStar, which is owned by Gannett. They should get credit for supporting a very expensive investigation.”

Jamil Smith, who writes for The Huffington Post and The Los Angeles Times, tweeted, “Nassar isn’t in prison without this journalism. Subscribe to your local paper today. http://interactives.indystar.com/news/standing/OutOfBalanceSeries/index2.html …”
